abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            unsatisfactory, though sustainability is likely, and modest
            institutional development impacts were achieved. Key lessons
            convey that common development objectives between the Bank,
            and Borrower are critical to pursue project implementation,
            and, that the Bank should ensure the appropriate
            implementation arrangements, particularly with implementing
            agencies. Specifically, in light of active participation of
            agencies (other than the Implementing Agency) separate
            Project Agreements, or comparable arrangements could
            authorize the Bank - should default occur - to suspend
            disbursements in the absence of compliance. Indeed, direct
            contractual agreements should be pursued with those entities
            that have the mandate to fulfill the requirements needed to
            meet the project's objective, and, the scope of these
            objectives must not be broader than the scope of the
            Borrower's operational capacity. Lack of clear leverage
            by the Bank, precluded the adherence of the implementing
            agency to both the implementation plan, and agreements
            (partly also because of the Borrower's financial
            capacity to undertake such a program on its own). Such being
            the case, the Bank should seek to expand the stake in the
            fulfillment of agreed actions, by including communities to
            form a wider range of stakeholders, who would then be
            empowered, and, responsible to sustain resources productively.
